science.headline: Networks Hold the Key to a Decades-Old Problem About Waves
science.teaser: Mathematicians are still trying to understand fundamental properties of the Fourier transform, one of their most ubiquitous and powerful tools. A new result marks an exciting advance toward that goal. The post Networks Hold the Key to a Decades-Old Problem About Waves first appeared on Quanta Magazi
science.tldr: Clarifies fundamental properties of the Fourier transform

science.headline: Intestinal macrophages modulate synucleinopathy along the gut–brain axis

science.tldr: Activates gut immune response to modulate neural diseases' progression effectively

science.headline: Cholinergic modulation of dopamine release drives effortful behaviour
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10046-6 In the nucleus accumbens, acetylcholine boosts dopamine release to promote effortful behaviour.
science.tldr: Increases understanding of how brain chemistry influences effortful human behavior

science.headline: How MAHA Exploits the Flaws of Modern Science
science.teaser: The Make America Healthy Again movement, which can be interpreted as a war on established science, has nevertheless revealed longstanding weaknesses in science’s key processes. C. Brandon Ogbunu argues that the time has come to confront these problems — already acknowledged by many in the community
science.tldr: Challenges scientific consensus and exposes underlying flaws in established knowledge

science.headline: Population-scale sequencing resolves determinants of persistent EBV DNA
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10020-2 Population-scale WGS reveals genetic determinants of persistent EBV DNA, linking immune regulation—especially antigen processing and MHC class II variation—to EBV persistence and heterogeneous disease associations.
science.tldr: Reveals the genetic causes of persistent EBV DNA infection

science.headline: Environmentally driven immune imprinting protects against allergy
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10001-5 In a mouse model, environmental immunostimulation in early life led to cross-reactive adaptive immune memory and reduced type II immune responses to allergens, indicating a mechanistic relationship between environmental antige
science.tldr: Protects against allergy by fostering immune system resilience in early life

science.headline: How War Is Hell for Birds, Too
science.teaser: Loyalty to homelands leave them in the path of danger The post How War Is Hell for Birds, Too appeared first on Nautilus .

science.headline: Projected impacts of climate change on malaria in Africa
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10015-z Projected impacts of climate change on malaria burden in Africa by 2050 highlight the urgent need for climate-resilient malaria control strategies and robust emergency response systems to safeguard progress towards malaria era
science.tldr: Increases malaria burden in Africa by 2050

science.headline: Multimodal learning with next-token prediction for large multimodal models
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10041-x Emu3 enables large-scale text, image and video learning based solely on next-token prediction, matching the generation and perception performance of task-specific methods, with implications for the development of scalable and
science.tldr: Predicts future tokens helps train large models on multimodal data effectively

science.headline: Prethermalization by random multipolar driving on a 78-qubit processor
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09977-x The existence of a long-lived, prethermal regime in many-body systems with tunable heating rates, driven by structured random protocols, is observed using a 78-qubit superconducting quantum processor.
science.tldr: Reveals new behavior in many-body systems with quantum processors

science.headline: Ann Druyan on How NASA’s Golden Records Got Made
science.teaser: A comic about humanity’s love letter to interstellar space The post Ann Druyan on How NASA’s Golden Records Got Made appeared first on Nautilus .
science.tldr: Reveals humanity's attempt to convey life and culture through interstellar space

science.headline: Pesticide residues alter taxonomic and functional biodiversity in soils
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09991-z A wide survey of pesticide effects on soil biodiversity across 373 sites in Europe reveals that pesticide residues occur in 70% of sites and have major effects on soil biodiversity and functional ecology.
science.tldr: Alters soil biodiversity with potentially long-term ecological consequences

philosophy.headline: In the Footsteps of Aeneas

Jewish people, whether of foreign provenance or Swiss-born and already living on Swiss territory, had been explicitly f

philosophy.headline: Value Capture in Philosophy
philosophy.teaser: “Value capture is… where your values are rich and subtle or in the process of developing that way. And you get put in a setting or near a technology or an institution that presents you with a simplified, typically quantified version, and the simplified version takes over.” That’s C. Thi Nguyen, prof
philosophy.tldr: Develops our understanding of what it means to truly capture value

philosophy.headline: The Music Never Stopped
philosophy.teaser: by Charles Siegel Sun went down in honey And the moon came up in wine You know the stars were spinning dizzy Lord the band kept us so busy We forgot about the time That is a verse from “The Music Never Stopped,” a song written by Bob Weir and John Barlow, and recorded on…
